description: Writing new code features, components, functions, or modules
principles: Code should be readable and self-documenting
Functionality should be correct and well-tested
Code should be maintainable and follow established patterns
Performance should be reasonable for the use case
Security should be considered from the start

input: Clear description of what needs to be built
Context about where it will be used

qualityCriteria.completeness: All required functionality implemented, no partially-done features
qualityCriteria.correctness: Code runs without errors, handles edge cases, produces expected output
qualityCriteria.consistency: Follows project's naming conventions, style, and architectural patterns
qualityCriteria.performance: Reasonable performance for typical use cases, no obvious inefficiencies
qualityCriteria.security: No obvious vulnerabilities, validates inputs, follows security best practices
qualityCriteria.maintainability: Clear variable/function names, comments on complex logic, easy to extend

commonPatterns: Include error handling and edge case coverage
Write at least basic tests or test cases
Consider backward compatibility if extending existing code
antiPatterns: Hardcoded values that should be configurable
Copy-paste code instead of creating reusable functions
